title: coronavirus-scotrail-offers-free-travel-unemployed----even-get-job
story: The coronavirus pandemic has had a huge impact on jobs in Scotland, with figures in May suggesting the number of people claiming unemployment benefit has increased by .% - up about , to ,.The travel firm say that the cost of travelling to an interview can ldquooften be a barrier to ing to work ndash so launched a scheme to fast-track the process.The idea was launched in , but has recently been marketed againby ScotRailas a result of the coronavirus.What can jobseekers get Those eligible can get two freejourneys a month to attend an interview.They can also then get a free ScotRail travel ticket for the first month of theirto work.Jobseekers are also able to take advantage of the Jobcentre Plus Travel Discount Card - a UK Government initiative which allows those who are unemployed and claiming Jobseekerrsquos Allowance or Universal Credit to receive a % discount on selected rail tickets.If youre out of work, were offering two free tickets per month for travel to interviews - as well as a free one month ticket once you secure a job.Am I eligible for the scheme To be eligible for any of these offers, the customer must have been claiming Jobseekers Allowance or Universal Credit for - monthsor - months .How does it work Tickets for travel to interview:For jobseekers to obtain up to two freetickets per month to attend interviews, their local Job Centre issues them with a completed authorisation form which should then be taken to a local station where staff will issue a ticket .One month ticket once employment secured:If the jobseeker secures employment and wishes to apply for a free monthrsquos ticket, their local Job Centre will issue them with a completed authorisation form which should then be taken to a station where staff will issue a ticket .What does ScotRail say ScotRail Alliance Managing Director Alex Hynes said: ldquoFor people out of work, the cost of travelling to an interview can often be a barrier to ing to work.ldquoBy removing that barrier and providing help with the cost, we hope to be able to support people into work and grow Scotlandrsquos economy.ldquoThe support we offer to jobseekers is one of the ScotRail Alliancersquos best kept secrets ndash but I want as many people as possible to know about this opportunity.

title: pubs-busy-open-first-time-months
story: Scottish Government-imposed restrictions to help fight the coronavirus pandemic were relaxed last week, with customers allowed back inside pubs, provided they followed social distancing.Businesses throughout the county were pleased to welcome back thirsty punters, with each reporting a busy weekend.Laura McSweeney, from The Green in Haddington, was pleased with how the weekend had gone.She said people had been ldquorespectful of the restrictions in place and the beer garden was proving popular, with the exception of during poor weather.She added: ldquoIt has been a bit of a mixture to be honest. The usual suspects are coming back but it has been a bit of an unusual time as people are heading back to work.ldquoOverall, we have had a lot more people come in for food and there has been quite a good turnout.Social distancing restrictions are in place at the Court Street pub, with signs reminding people of the restrictions.Meanwhile, staff are wearing visors when serving customers both inside and outside the building.Hand sanitiser is also available, with a strict cleaning schedule in place for the toilets as well.Victoria Fowler, at Musselburghrsquos Sportsman Bar, described trade as ldquoabsolutely brilliant over the weekend.She told the Courier: ldquoIt was much better than we expected.ldquoEverybody seems to be following the rules.ldquoWe were full all the time and having to turn people away.Despite the restrictions, Victoria said the pub, on the townrsquos High Street, had been busy.As well as social distancing, bar stools have been removed, while customers are not allowed to bring their empty glasses back to the bar.Similar to The Green, there is also a rigorous cleaning regime in place as well.William Gordon, manager at The Brig Inn in Tranent, said the beer garden had been full and there had been a good number of visitors.He added that ious restrictions had also been put in place but people seemed to be enjoying themselves.Chief Inspector Neil Mitchell, local area commander, had attended Haddingtonrsquos community council, which was held online, last week.Chris McEwan, vice-chairman of the group, asked what measures police were putting in place ahead of the first weekend of people drinking inside pubs.The senior officer said that licensing officers had liaised with each of the licensed premises across East Lothian ahead of them reopening.He noted that many were simply too small to have a great number of visitors when social distancing was taken into account and officers would be out over the weekend.He said: ldquoRight through the whole of East Lothian, [licensed premises] are really keen to make sure they provide a safe environment for customers.ldquoIf they do that, there will be far less people within their premises.ldquoWe will deal with any complaints in the normal manner.Writing in his Courier column this week, Ch Insp Mitchell was pleased to say that the weekend had gone smoothly.He wrote: ldquoOur licensed premises and restaurants re-opened in line with the Scottish Government guidance and I am really pleased to say that we had no incidents reported and everyone enjoyed themselves sensibly.

title: virtual-meetings-become-new-normal-council
story: The local authority has signed up to web service Connect Remote at a cost of more than pound, for its first year, to ensure councillors can meet once emergency measures introduced during lockdown are lted.A report to councillors says the service is the latest tool offered by web company Public-i, which already provides web casting facilities to more than  councils, including Midlothian and Edinburgh.It will allow councillors to take part in virtual meetings which are live-streamed and can be accessed by the public as well as being put into an archive to watch back later.Currently some scrutiny meetings have been held via Skype for Business as the council strives to make decisions in public however, a report to councillors said that system was not a ldquolong-term solution for large-scale meetings.It said: ldquoLicences are required for inidual users , administrator s are limited, and it is dficult to manage public lsquoattendancersquo.Instead, the report said, officers had been looking at alternatives as it became clear face to face meetings might not resume for some time.It said: ldquoOfficers have been looking at a iety of options for continuing the democratic process in a way that replicates face-to-face meetings, as well as being accessible by the public.ldquoConnect Remote is a web-based system, so inidual user licences are not required and there is no need to software to be installed on usersrsquo IT equipment."It will allow members and officers to participate in meetings remotely, as well as providing members of the public with access to proceedings, either as they happen or via archived recordings.The report said year one costs for establishing and maintaining the new system were pound,, which would be classedas Covid- related funding and could attract Government support.

title: great-grandmother-celebrates-95th-birthday-95-plus-cards
story: Betty Sneddonwas delighted when relatives paid her a visit on Sunday to wish her many happy s and enjoy a socially distanced party in the garden of her town centre home.She did not want any gts but her family thought it would be a great ideashe received  cards ndash reflecting her age ndash from well-wishers.The number of cards sent has now surpassed the target as relatives and friends, some from abroad, inundated her with birthday messages, much to her surprise and amazement.During the Covid- lockdown, Mrs Sneddon enjoyed spending time in her beloved garden. She was also grateful to a friend who left cakes for her and gave her a wave.Her daughter Mary Blair kept her in touch with family via FaceTime but she was delighted to catch up with them in person on her birthday amid the easing of restrictions.The last surviving member of a family of nine ndash five brothers and four sisters ndash Mrs Sneddon was born in Musselburghrsquos Newbigging, where she first attended school.She was a pupil at Burgh Primary School and went on to secondary school at Fisherrow. She also lived for a time in Kilwinning.On leaving school, she was employed as a housemaid at Inveresk for a short time and also worked at Bruntonrsquos Wire Mill, Musselburgh. She also enjoyed working at LrsquoAperit, a restaurant in Edinburgh.She met her future husband Jimmy Sneddon when he was staying in lodgings in Musselburgh while working as a steel erector at Portobello Power Station. The couple were married at Inveresk Manse and set up home on Moir Avenue.Mrs Sneddon was a soprano and soloist in the famous Musselburgh Fishwives Choir.They sang all over the country and once went to sing for soldiers in recovery after the Second World War at Peel Hospital near Peebles. Her older brother Jim was recovering at the hospital from a severe back injury.A mum of three, grandmother of five and great grandmother of three, she has always filled her le with family and friends.Over the years, she enjoyed attending the Womenrsquos Rural Institute and playing Scrabble with Nancy Herkes, her best friend from school, until they were in their late seventies.A fan of detective programmes and brain-teasers, she said her recipe for a long and happy le was ldquocrosswords, Scrabble, gardening and great grandchildren keep you going ndash not forgetting Morse, Poirot and, of course, good genes.

title: tantallon-dirleton-castles-reopen-within-weeks
story: Dirleton Castle and Tantallon Castle, near North Berwick, have been closed to visitors by Historic Environment Scotlandduring the coronavirus pandemic.Now, restrictions are easing and Scotlandrsquos biggest operator of visitor attractions has revealed ldquoa phased approach to reopen  per cent of its free-to-access and ticketed properties by mid-September.HESrsquo website lists both Dirleton Castle and Tantallon Castle among  sites which it hopes to start opening from late August onwards ldquoon a rolling basis.ldquoThese sites will open in consultation with the local communities and reflecting circumstances in each area as much as possible, the website states.Alex Paterson, chief executive of HES, said: ldquoAt the forefront of our planning is the safety of our staff and visitors, whilst being able to reopen for the tourist season by gradually enabling safe access to our properties and facilities in line with Scottish Government guidance.ldquoWersquove been working exceptionally hard to ensure our properties will be accessible and ready to welcome visitors however, itrsquos important that we implement our resumption plans at the right time given the dferent requirements for each site.ldquoThis also includes looking at the ying local and regional requirements throughout the country and we have considered this when setting out our phased approach to welcoming visitors back and supporting Scotlandrsquos tourism and economic recovery.From last Wednesday, HES provided access to more than  unstaffed and key-keeper sites across Scotland, where physical distancing can be readily maintained and where HES can provide free and safe access.When the attractions reopen, visitors, including members, will be required to pre-book tickets online and use contactless payment where possible one-way systems will be implemented in some locations and some areas of sites, such as enclosed spaces, will be closed off.Visitor numbers will also be limited for safety reasons.Mr Paterson added: ldquoWersquore very much looking forward to welcoming visitors back.ldquoThere will of course be some initial changes, including managing visitor numbers at certain sites, as well as restricting access to specic locations, but we can assure visitors of a warm welcome.ldquoWe want to ask our visitors to help create a safe environment by behaving responsibly and following our guidance at properties, and we will be providing further information on our website for visitors to help them prepare for their visit.For more information, visit historicenvironment.scot

title: impressive-turnout-farmers-market-returns-town
story: The market ed to the townrsquos Court Street last Saturday, July , with an impressive turnout.Now, it is getting ready toagain tomorrow .The visitor numbers were revealed by Councillor John McMillan, who represents Haddington on East Lothian Council.The local authorityrsquos spokesman for economic development and tourism told members of the townrsquos community council: ldquoAt the farmersrsquo market,  people came in, which is good for the town centre.The popular markets, which sell locally sourced products, had disappeared from the town for four months due to the coronavirus pandemic.However, the organisers worked with East Lothian Council and Police Scotland, among other groups, to see the marketon July .Steps were taken to ensure public safety at the event, with the introduction of a one-way system on Court Street.Visitors to the market entered beside the Corn Exchange before heading towards Brewery Lane and then turning back and leaving through a signed exit.Members of Haddington Rotary Club acted as stewards, while a headcount was also taken.The one-way system will remain in place for Saturdayrsquos market, with a total of  stalls expected to be open.Similarly, hand sanitising stations and stewards will again be on hand to try to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.Val Shields, chair of Haddington Farmersrsquo Market, was delighted to say the ing market had proven a great success.She told the Courier: ldquoI think everybody was pleased with it.ldquoIt was a nice relaxed atmosphere.ldquoPeople all did the things they were meant to do and were very patient and kept social distances.ldquoStallholders were quite happy to be back and takings were reasonable overall.ldquoThe weather was nice and everything aligned.ldquoIt was just a good day and everyone ndash customers and stallholders ndash was glad to be back.

title: plans-new-sports-pavilion-north-berwick-get-go-ahead
story: It will be located on land north-east of Wotherspoon Green and have an adjacent car park with  spaces, two of which will be for electric vehicles, with a charger point, and three for disabled users.Final plans for the car park area changed slightly from initial designs, including the entrance to the car park being moved and a path that led to the building removed.The interior of the single-storey building has not changed and will contain two changing rooms, each with a separate shower and toilet, two toilets, a plant room, storage cupboard, clubroom and accessible toilet.There will also be two bike racks.The application received six objections, all of which related to loss of privacy, loss of daylight, concerns relating to the use of floodlights, the buildingrsquos visual appearance, an increase in road traffic and pedestrians, and increase in noise at anti-social hours.The sports pavilion, which could be named after the late Pilmar Smith ndash a North Berwick legend who was former vice-chairman of Heart of Midlothian Football Club and former chairman of Lothian Buses ndash will not have floodlights.A council planning officerrsquos report said: ldquoThe sports pavilion is directly related to the future provision of the sports pitch to the south and would serve as a recreational facility for North Berwick and the existing and future residents of the wider Mains Farm development site.It is not known when work will begin on the building due to the current coronavirus restrictions.

title: community-resilience-groups-cockenzie-port-seton-dunbar-gullane-haddington-humbie-musselburgh-north-berwick-prestonpans-tranent-elphinstone-work-hard
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at nine of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Cockenzie and Port Seton. Picture: Google MapsCockenzie and Port SetonWHILE work goes on to wind down the resilience effort and prepare the community in Cockenzie and Port Seton for le after lockdown, volunteers have continued to provide assistance and receive donations.The local resilience effort has been led by Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council, which has this week continued to pay tribute to its volunteers on social media.The craft club at Chalmers Memorial Church has been making masks and donated some to the resilience team.Meanwhile, local people, including those in Longniddry, can visit the pantry at Port Seton Centre for food and other items.Delivery is also available by phoning the centre on  .Throughout lockdown, East Lothian Council staff at the centre have been making meals and, alongside resilience volunteers, delivering them to residents.Thanks was also given from Preston Seton Gosford Area Partnership to Scotmid for the donation of deodorant and body wash it gave to the centre when it went to pick up toiletries for the pantry.The resilience effort will wind down either at the end of the month or when children go back to school in August.Contact detailsTo contact the Cockenzie and Port Seton resilience team, call  .DunbarDunbarCOMMUNITY resilience volunteers in Dunbar are getting ready to hand over the reins to East Lothian Council.Volunteers from throughout the town and neighbouring West Barns have been working to support vulnerable members of the two communities.The community resilience team will take a step back at the end of the month.George Robertson, chairman of Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership, said a lot of volunteers were already stepping away due to work commitments or to go on holiday.He said: ldquoIrsquove found it to be in some ways quite rewarding because it was very gratying to see what a positive response we had from the local community and how people stepped forward as volunteers."This started in mid-March when we set up those teams, we have come a long way now. People are getting fatigued and quite glad to be stepping down and do less.The community was split into nine clusters, with each assigned a lead volunteer.George told the Courier that the busiest cluster would receive about  calls a week when restrictions were at their peak.People would collect prescriptions and shopping, as well as take dogs for a walk.Hot meals were also delivered to those in need while volunteers worked with Dunbarrsquos foodbank.Electronic devices were also blanked and given a new lease of le with students in the town who were studying from home with schools closed.However, as restrictions have eased, George said the number of calls had ldquodropped right off.Volunteers have agreed to be on hand in case of a second spike and will be ready to ramp up their efforts should the need arise.Contact detailsTo contact the Dunbar resilience team, email Dunbar.covid@gmailGullane. more volunteers than we require to provide a service but we have been happy to be there."Everybody has been happy to be involved and be availablerequired.He added a lot of neighbours were looking  or at prestonpansresilience@gmailTranent. title: bid-drive-thru-coffee-shop-eyesore-service-area
story: The Motor Fuel Group has applied to East Lothian Council for planning permission to build a coffee shop with drive-thru and create additional car parking.There would also be a new dedicated entrance to serve the adjacent Travelodge hotel.More than  jobs would be created as a result of the development.The hotel used to share an entrance with the now vacant Burger King and Little Chef restaurants, which closed several years ago.The site is located close to Old Craighall Roundabout which connects the A Edinburgh City Bypass to the A.North of the site is the B that connects to Monktonhall and then Musselburgh beyond, with the town centre .km from the service area.Tony Thomas, director of East Linton-based APT Planning and Development, said: ldquoThe plan is to demolish part of the original building complex that previously housed Burger King and Little Chef, and create a more dedicated and convenient car park for the Travelodge.ldquoOn the western part of the site we are proposing a drive-thru coffee outlet. Apart from that, the site will be landscaped and upgraded.He said that the current petrol station there, also owned by the Motor Fuel Company, would remain in use.Mr Thomas could not yet say which company would run the drive-thru coffee shop however, an image of the proposed outlet shows a logo for Starbucks.He said it was hoped the work would be completed within a yearplanning consent was granted.A landscape design report, submitted with the planning application, said the ldquoenhanced car park arrangement would provide nine accessible parking bays close to the building entrances and five electric car charging points.It added: ldquoWith the proposed coffee shop there is an opportunity to provide two areas of external seating ndash these have been carefully sited to maximise a south-facing aspect so that visitors can make the most of sunshine.ldquoBoth of these seating areas have plant beds located close by.ldquoThese beds will help to create a sense of enclosure."These plant beds will be planted with a iety of trees, shrubs and hardy perennial plants that will provide seasonal interest.ldquoThe plants will also help to screen any queuing cars into the drive-thru.ldquoTo the front of the retained Travelodge building, we have proposed another plant bed, planted with native trees ndash birch and rowan ndash and robust groundcover.ldquoElsewhere in the new car park, we have looked to punctuate the space with street trees these trees will help to provide vertical structure to the space.ldquoThe proposals look to retain the dense group of semi-mature trees to the west of the site.ldquoTo the north of the site there is a row of sycamore trees that will also be retained.ldquoWith the demolition of the building, there will be a gap in these trees and it is proposed that an additional four sycamore trees are planted to complete the row.ldquoThese trees will work as a buffer between the new car park and the road.ldquoTo make way for the development we are proposing to remove five small trees within the car park that have failed to establish.Other tree planting will take place around the site.Irene Tait, chair of Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council, welcomed the plan, saying: ldquoIt is an eyesore at the moment and something needed to be done for a while ndash as long as the landscaping fits in with the rest of the area.Ward councillor Stuart Currie, who is not a member of the councilrsquos planning committee, added: ldquoA big part of the site has been lying empty for some time and has become a real eyesore.ldquoThe entire site is already set up as a drive-thru facility alongside the hotel so, as long as itrsquos contained within the current boundary [Irsquom happy to support it].ldquoIt will create jobs and be brought back into full use from a boarded-up building.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothianrsquos MP, said: ldquoThere seems merit in it."Itrsquos a gap site and the facilities would enhance the area.ldquoAs long as it abides by any criteria set by council, the work and project seem welcome.

title: nurses-covid-19-efforts-win-hotel-stay-anywhere-world
story: Alison Williams, a research nurse at the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh, was nominated in the holiday competition by Rock My World Travel of North Berwick.The -year-old Edinburgh resident, who visited North Berwick on holidays as a child, has been branded a ldquosuperhero after raising more than pound, in her campaign to create lsquoRainbow Boxesrsquo for patients.The campaign started after Alison witnessed first-hand that several patients had few personal items as family members were unable to visit them, so did not have basic items such as pyjamas and toiletries.She said: ldquoA lot of people were being admitted in emergency situations so they didnrsquot have and were missing essential items, from nightwear to phone chargers.She added that other initiatives aimed to help nurses, whereas this specically helped patients.The mum of two, who studied at Napier University and qualied in , then came up with the idea to get these items to the patients and launched a campaign on a local Facebook group, Edinburgh Gossip Girls, with the original aim of raising pound to create the boxes.To date the total stands at more than pound,, with a further pound, donated from RBS, bringing the total raised to more than pound,.Alison said: ldquoThe pound target was smashed in a few minutes.She now has a small team of people supporting her.She added: ldquoWe have enough money to last until October but hopefully things will be back to normal [by then] and people can come in on visits and the need wonrsquot be as great.Boxes are delivered to all  wards in the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh, as well as nearby hospices and the East Lothian Community Hospital in Haddington.Her campaign, alongside her job as a nurse and working during the current coronavirus crisis, led to her being nominated in the holiday competition by Rock My World Travel.The competition was featured in Travel Weekly, a travel industry trade magazine, and run by travel company Stuba, in recognition of the hard work of local heroes who have emerged during the pandemic.People were in with a chance of winning a pound hotel voucher. Alison was one of  national winners.Isobel McCardie, who runs Rock My World Travel alongside her husband Mark, nominated Alison.Isobel, who lives in North Berwick, said: ldquoWhen I saw what Alison was doing, it instantly resonated with me.ldquoNot only was she on the frontline fighting Covid-, but her compassion for the patients inspired her to go further.ldquoAs soon as I saw the competition, I instantly thought of Alison. She has been completely selfless in this entire task and is working tirelessly, I canrsquot think of anyone who deserves a break more.On the nomination, Alison said: ldquoI only knew about it when she phoned me and told me Irsquod won. Itrsquos really nice that someone who doesnrsquot know me nominated me. Itrsquos amazing and flattering.Alison plans to take her colleague Rachel, who has been working tirelessly to help Alison with her campaign.When askedshe had decided where to go, Alison said: ldquoIrsquom not wanting to go too far. Irsquoll possibly go somewhere in Scotland.

title: alcohol-confiscated-youths-sent-back-midlothian
story: As the Covid- restrictions are slowly eased, policing and our response is ing to a more recognised model.This week we have reinstated our appointments system where we can again come to you at a convenient time that fits into your day, deal with your enquiry over the phone or attend immediately where required.Officers are slowly ing to their normal working locations with new social distancing measures implemented and calls we are attending are more like what I would expect at this time of year.Face masks, particularly on public transport and in shops, have been a hot topic and the current guidance is that they must be worn.Police officers in the exercise of their duty are exempt from this however, I have instructed that unless it is an emergency, my officers will wear face masks in shops and on transport.In my last few columns, I have commented on a rise in large groups of youths congregating and in some instances causing anti-social behaviour.Over the past few weeks I have had additional patrols and resources allocated to this and we have worked closely with East Lothian Council Safer Community Team.What we have found is that groups of youths have been coming down from Midlothian and engaging in disorder with some youths from East Lothian.At the weekend, my officers dealt with a large gathering of youths who were dispersed and got buses back up to Midlothian.Some youths were charged, alcohol was confiscated and others will receive a letter home addressed to their parents through our Parental Advisory Lettersystem.This early action prevented disorder occurring later in the day and we will continue to do this over the coming weeks.Our road and speed checks across the hotspot and coastal areas continue and we have contributed signicantly to the national summer drug drink driving campaign.Our licensed premises and restaurants re-opened in line with the Scottish Government guidance and I am really pleased to say that we had no incidents reported and everyone enjoyed themselves sensibly.The beaches and beauty spots continue to bring people from all over Scotland and, now with the English school holidays started, further afield.Last weekend I witnessed first-hand the fantastic work done by East Lothian Council employees to keep the areas safe and clean in very challenging circumstances.The next stage of lockdown is still a while away and I ask that you all continue to follow the current guidelines set to keep yourself and others safe.If you are getting a holiday, I hope it is a pleasant one and that you get good weather to enjoy it.

title: wildlife-diary-studying-kingfisher
story: Although Zan has always had an interest in photography, it was after moving to Scotland that she discovered a passion for wildle and now spends every spare moment pursuing that endeavour.This has led her to volunteering for multiple wildle charities, as well as studying for an MSc in Wildle, Biology and Conservation alongside her photography. In this monthly column, she shares her wildle diary ndash and pictures!DURING lockdown, I was trying to make the most of my free time ndash going on daily walks, working on my website, editing photos from before lockdown, designing my first book and completing A LOT of jigsaws .After the lockdown restrictions started to ease, I was able to spend even more time outdoors than I would normally do. I dedicated June to visiting dferent local sites to watch the kingfisher ndash which you may remember from my previous article ndash a family of wrens and the brown hares.One evening, as I was uploading my photographs on to social media and searching through the pages, I came across a few images of a bird that every birder wanted to see since its influx to the UK was published. It was a rosy starling!The beautul rosy starlinglooks nothing like the starlings we know. It strongly resembles a magpiewith a much shorter tail.This species is unmistakable in its adult plumage. The male has a pale pink body with a black head, wings, and tail. Additionally, during the breeding season the male develops a wispy crest and the black colour becomes glossier with a purplish green or blue sheen.The female is less vibrant than the male. Both sexes appear much duller outside of their breeding season.Furthermore, the rosy starling does not mimic other species, unlike its well-known cousin.What the two species have in common is murmuration ndash an astonishing and mesmerising aerial spectacle large flocks of these birds gather and perform a real show as they swoop, e and swirl across the sky in beautul shape-shting clouds. It is a phenomenon that pleases the eye of every observer.The rosy starlingrsquos breeding area stretches from the Balkans and Turkey to Central Asia and north-west China. It spends winters in India and south-east Arabia. As a strongly migratory species, it can travel outside of its normal breeding range. As a result, there are signicant periodic summer and autumn influxes in western Europe. The causes of such irruptions are not yet fully understood however, it appears to be related to changes in the population of locusts on which the birds feed.Imagine my amazement when I read that one of those birds had landed and made its temporary home in someonersquos garden in Port Seton!The cherry on the cake was that the night when I saw the first images of the rosy starling in East Lothian, I also received an email from Stuart Payne ndash the lucky host of the rosy starling. Stuart invited me to his garden.The next morning, my fianceacute Chris and I rushed to Port Seton. As we were walking towards Stuartrsquos house, we saw another birder looking around hoping to spot the rosy starling. As soon as we arrived at Stuartrsquos house, I saw this magnicent pink bird flying past the house and landing on the bird feeder to start its feast.Stuart and his we Gillian welcomed us in their garden, where I spent half an hour photographing the gorgeous rosy starling and chatting to Stuart and Gillian. I also took some time to admire their beautul dogs Hugo and Hobbes. These dogs were just wonderful, not every day you see dogs as well behaved as these two!My first and, I hope, not last experience with the rosy starling was unforgettable! I am incredibly grateful to Stuart and Gillian for reaching out to me and inviting me over. You wouldnrsquot be reading this article about the rosy starlingnot for the two of them!If there is any particular species yoursquod like to read about or have a rare visitor to your garden yoursquod like to share with me, donrsquot hesitate to get in touch through my website or social media channels.Speak to you next month!zanslensfacebook zanslensinstagram zans_lenstwitter zans_lens

title: pictures-prestonpans-lockdown-gala-day
story: Like many events in the county, the annual Prestonpans Childrenrsquos Gala was impacted by the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.The galarsquos organising committee had several discussions and, following advice from both East Lothian Council and the Scottish Government, it first postponed and then cancelled the gala day, which had been due to be held on June .However, the committee still wanted to recognise and mark the day.One suggestion was to give all of those in the royal court a goodie bag and rename the event, so instead it held what it called lsquoLockdown Gala Dayrsquo.Graeme Hutchison, gala convenor, told the Courier: ldquoThis was to encourage the kids and remind them that we hadnrsquot forgotten that this should have been their special day.ldquoThis idea kind of grew thanks to our chairperson Vikki Burns suggesting we could have an alternative gala day parade.The parade consisted of the gala committee members decorating their cars with balloons and bows in gala colours.They then travelled around Prestonpans, stopping at the houses of each member of the royal court to deliver them their goodie bag, honking their horns as they passed.Graeme said: ldquoIn the lead-up to gala day there was still a buzz about the town people were still showing their support by putting up their bunting and the parents of the royal court were being made aware we would be visiting. Nobody knew what to expect.ldquoGala day itself was amazing, from the glorious weather to the great response we got from the locals as we travelled around in convoy tooting and waving, visiting many streets of the town which the normal gala parade doesnrsquot visit. The people of Prestonpans certainly came out to show their support and for that we are truly grateful.ldquoWe would like to take this opportunity to thank the future Queen Lily [Bennion] and her royal court, as well as their families for their patience and understanding. Thanks to Connor from Sneddon Media for travelling with us and capturing the fantastic photos, which are on our Facebook page lsquoPrestonpans Gala Dayrsquo.ldquoFinally, thanks to the dedicated committee members who once again gave up their time to make the event possible.ldquoWe hope to be back doing some fundraisers in the not too distant future to help us fund and prepare as we look forward to Gala Day  on Saturday, June .After Lockdown Gala Day, Graeme took to social media to share his thoughts on the event.He said: ldquoPrestonpans, you didnrsquot disappoint us.ldquoThe fantastic efforts made from everyone to put up your bunting and decorate your streets, please repeat this next year. It was great to see so many of you as we travelled around as many streets as we could while visiting the members of the royal court.ldquoTo the royal court children, we didnrsquot want to forget that it would have been your day, we can still have your special day next year.ldquoTo Queen Lily, you were absolutely stunning, even reducing some of the committee to tears your mum and dad will be proud of you, the way you conducted yourself on what should have been your special day. To you, the community of Prestonpans for coming out and showing your appreciation as we passed by quietlyin our cars, doing the alternative gala parade. Hopefully you enjoyed it.He also thanked his fellow gala committee members for giving up their time and ensuring gala day traditions continued.

title: pop-up-cycle-lane-coastal-road
story: The local authority received pound.million from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Spaces for People fund to introduce measures to make it easier to social distance in town centres and improve cycle and pedestrian paths.And it has revealed that the next phase of work will involve establishing a temporary cycle lane between Prestonpans and Cockenzie, along the main road.It will also see the speed limit on the road, which is normally mph, reduced to mph and speed limits in the twocommunities reduced to just mph.The council has already received two strikes over its ambitious plans to transform its town centres this month, with u-turns made twice on projects.At the start of July it unveiled its plans, which included introducing parking suspensions across town centres as it looked to create more space outside shops and relocate parking away from high streets.In Haddington town centre there was a furious response after cones and parking suspension notices went up over the first weekend of the changes, leaving traders and their customers fuming.Shop owners who had only just opened their doors feared the restrictions would stop costumers fromcoming to the market town and within days the council announced it was putting parking suspensions in all town centres on hold.Then last week, it announced plans to transform tourist hotspot North Berwickrsquos town centre and create a temporary -space car park on its iconic Elcho Green ndash a much-loved publicspace and putting green.The response from the community, including Solheim Cup captain Catriona Matthew, who voiced concern at losing green space like the Green, saw those plans also shelved as the local authority insisted it was a ldquolistening council and would carry out further consultation.The latest plan for a three-metre-wide cycle lane between Prestonpans and Cockenziewill see dozens of painted stones created by local schoolchildren, which line the footpath, moved however, the council said it has agreed with the local community council for them to be collected and relocated across he road.Councillor Norman Hampshire, environment spokesperson, said: ldquoWe received many comments in the public consultation around Spaces for People on the need to provide suitable space for people cycling.ldquoMany people are currently cycling this route and we need to cater for the current increase in cyclists during the Covid- pandemic period.ldquoIn common with other Spaces for People measures, this route is for temporary use as we gradually move out of restrictions and will also provide a viable alternative to the use of the private car and or public transport for shorter-distanced essential or leisure trips in the area.The works will also include the introduction of temporary crossings of Edinburgh Road at either end of the route through the use of lsquobuildoutsrsquo and bolt-down bollards.MrHampshire added: ldquoWe were aware of a collection of painted stones that have been carefully laid by local schoolchildren alongside the existing footway along Edinburgh Road and recognise that these are important to the local community.ldquoThe community council has arranged for these to be carefully collected prior to the start of the works and have been relocated on the other side of the road.

title: column-job-figures-worrying
story: Furloughing has worked but unemployment is creeping up.Keeping folk in work and creating new jobs through investment in necessary public works is essential.Whether broadband, new council housing or retrofitting older homes and schools, therersquos things that need done and willing hands to do them.Itrsquos another reason why itrsquos good to see cafes, pubs and restaurants reopening.People work in them, as well as customers welcoming the socialisation just as much as the food and drink on offer.It wonrsquot be easy for owners, as social distancing requirements make it awkward and necessary hygiene rules also impact.Itrsquos also the case that some just wonrsquot be able to reopen as theyrsquore just not able to meet the rules or make a living under them.Itrsquos why the Chancellor should extend the furlough, as in France and other countries, to support those businesses until they can.In the interim, as with this paperrsquos laudable campaign to shop local, we should all try and support local venues.Parliament this week again considered trade and proposed new deals with the USA and other countries.But as with unemployment, whatrsquos creeping out is frightening.I took part in a discussion hosted by Trade Justice International which had representatives from the NFU, RSPCA and other far from radical groups, all of whom expressed concern.Indeed, an NFU petition has gathered over one million signatures.Chlorinated chicken has dominated the headlines but whatrsquos becoming clear is thatrsquos not the least of the threats, repugnant enough as it is.The whole treatment of animals is done with little care for their welfare, let alone those that work in the sector or for consumers who buy the product.Cheap food imports are heralded by the Tory Government, but they come at a price thatrsquoll be paid by hard-working local farmers and all of us in what wersquore forced to eat.

title: column-much-enjoy-preston-seton-gosford
story: For many, foreign holidays have already passed or been cancelled, would be too expensive to book at this late stage, or they do not want to take either the health or financial risk of booking one. So the lure of the staycation has become attractive to many for the first time and, luckily being in East Lothian, we have plenty to keep us entertained.We have a huge number of attractions, whether that be our numerous world-renowned golf courses, the nationally recognised National Museum of Flight and Scottish Seabird Centre in North Berwick, or as one of Scotlandrsquos premier coastal destinations for food and drink.What always interests me is that there is so much available that not everyone knows everything. I am often struck by people not knowing some of the sites in my ward of Preston, Seton and Gosford. Therefore, I thought this week I would take the opportunity to plug them and encourage you to visit us.To start in the west of the ward in Prestonpans exists the Prestonpans Murals Trail, which is made of over  pieces of art, and depicts the townrsquos culture and history.This includes murals on its witch hunts, industrial past, the influence on famous conservationist John Muirrsquos early le, and relation with migration both to and from Scotland ndash well worth a few hoursrsquo walk around the town.Also in the town there is the unappreciated Preston Tower, a structure with parts still standing from the th century. It is a one-of-a-kind building, with dferent parts and floors having been added over the years and other bits destroyed since it was first built.Currently it isnrsquot open but Prestonpans Community Council has been pushing to get it in a fit state so that the people of Prestonpans can truly benefit from this one-of-a-kind building.Moving east into Cockenzie and Port Seton, next to the harbour is the  Waggonway Museum. It is a fantastic museum and project that tells the story of the arearsquos extensive industrial history, including of the Tranent-Cockenzie Waggonway, built in  and associated with the coal and salt industries.Nearby sits Cockenzie House, a mansion and gardens dating from the th century. It is now home to a brilliant wee cafe and numerous craft businesses well worth a visit.In between Longniddry and Port Seton sits Seton Colligate Church, considered ldquoone of the finest medieval collegiate churches in Scotland. It was built in the late s by landowner Lord Seton so the community of priests could pray for his familyrsquos salvation.Finally on the coast there is Longniddry Bents, East Lothian largest tourist attraction. It is a beautul stretch of coastline home to a large iety of wildle, including many types of birds, voles and seals.Soyou are having a staycation this summer, visit the Preston, Seton and Gosford area and, whilst here, support our local cafes, shops, restaurants and pubs.

title: letter-it-act-vandalism
story: Today we are faced with a proposal to turn part of one of these beautul natural sites, in a designated conservation area, into an unsightly car park.Having been born and brought up in North Berwick and able to take advantage of the foresight of our forefathers, I was astonished to find not only that the proposal had been lsquoapprovedrsquo, but that it had been made at all. This is a vulnerable site and the suggestion of lsquotemporaryrsquo use is no guarantee.I am well aware of the problems of parking in our commercially vibrant High Street and all the efforts made over the years to come up with a solution.But parking cars on Elcho Green, a uniquely placed recreational facility for young and old, is not one of them. It would be an act of vandalism comparable with covering the gravestones in the old graveyard, which from a parking point of view would be even more convenient.George Finlayson CMG CVOCraigleith ViewNorth Berwick

title: tims-tales-little-red-riding-hood-wee-rud
story: THERE wis yince a young lassie carsquod Wee Rud. She wis carsquod Wee Rud cause whenever she gaed oot, she wore a rud hoodie. So her pals gied her that nickname, ater the story aboot Wee Rud Riding Hood.Wee Rud hud missed her grandma awfy much durin the lockdoon. She hud spoken tae her oan the computer, but that wasnae the same. Shersquod missed her hugs and the smell orsquo soup in her hoose.Sae when the lockdoon wis being lted, Wee Rud asked her mither: ldquoCan I gang tae grandmarsquos noo Her mither smiled. She understood how hard it hud bin: ldquoAye darlin, yer allowed noo, she will huv missed ye tae.Wee Rud jumped up n doon in wi joy. She packed a basket fu orsquo cakes she hud learnt tae bake during the lockdoon, and gied her ma a wee cheerio kiss.ldquoDinnae forget, gang straight tae grandmarsquos hoose, her mither said. ldquoDinnae footer aboot alang the way and mind no tae talk tae ony wolves.ldquoAye, dinnae worry ma, said Wee Rud, ldquoIrsquoll be carefu I ken the rules.Wee Rud wis a clever lass. She kent a wolf hud been hangin aboot, following folk an eatin grandmas. It wis a gye sleekit creature, it kent how tae hide and trick ye. But Wee Rud wis mair clever, she kent how tae keep safe frae it.She saw the wolf but she wisnae scared. She kept her distance and gied him a wee smirk as she went oan her way tae her grandmarsquos hoose.Wee Rud knocked oan her grandmarsquos door and gaed in. ldquoGranny itrsquos me! Wee Rud! Irsquove brought ye some cakes. I baked them masel.Her grandma stairted tae greet. They were tears orsquo joy, not sorrow, fir she hud missed her beloved Wee Rud sae much. They hugged sae tight their een near popped oot!ldquoYe gang ben the hoose wi thae cakes an Irsquoll put oan a cup orsquo tea, and wersquoll have a richt guid blether, said grandma.While Wee Rud wis putting the cakes oan the coffee table, her grandma came wi the tea. Wee Rud telt her grandma that she hud seen the wolf skulking aboot, but that shersquod flung him a deefie.ldquoGuid lass, said Grandma, ldquothat wolf is a richt sleekit creature, but noo that we ken his tricks we can change the story. They baith laughed.But the wolf wisnae laughing, he wis angry. It couldnae get intae the hoose tae eat grandma. Wee Rud hud bin tae clever.Ater huvin a braw time wi her gran, Wee Rud gied her another hug and left fir hame.Wee Rud arrived back at her hoose wi a happy shine oan her face. ldquoIt wis sae nice tae see Grandma, she said tae her mither.But the wolf wasnae happy in fact he wis ragin. ldquoThis isnae how the story is supposed tae be, he said tae himself, ldquoshersquos supposed tae break the rules and I get intae her grandmarsquos hoose and eat her.Just then, twa nurses were passin by oan their way tae work and heard whit the wolf said.ldquoAye weel, that lassie wis wise tae ye, and so are we, they said.They picked up a stick and waved it in the air, and the wolf ran away.Noo it wis the wolf that wis feart.It looked for ither folk tae follow but noo people kent its tricks and sae it didnae hae much orsquo a chance tae eat grannies onymair.The story hud been changed by Wee Rud, and she hud a wee laugh every time she thocht aboot it.And her grandma wis richt pleased she hudnae been scoffed by the wolf, thanks tae the wisdom orsquo her granddaughter.

title: road-closed-work-continues-dunbar-east-beach
story: Work resumed on improving the beach earlier this month after it was halted by the coronavirus pandemic.The works, which also aim to protect neighbouring Lamer Street, come after several years of discussion.Now, as part of the works, a section of the street from Woodbush to Stable Court will close from tomorrowuntil the end of September.Access to the two streets will be maintained, along with emergency access.Sand on the beach had disappeared due to coastal erosion, with a solution to attempt to restore the beach to how it once looked finally agreed upon earlier this year.Previously, consideration was given to importing sand from where but that was ruled out due to cost and the risk of it being washed away.Now, work is being carried out to see the construction of a breakwater at the southern end of the beach, with the existing groyne refurbished.Rock armour is also being created and will be put in place at the toe of the seawall.

title: coronavirus-poll-scots-support-another-lockdown-second-wave-occurs
story: In the study carried out by YouGov, % of people ldquostrongly support the idea of full measures being introduced in the event of a second wave, with a further % ldquosomewhat supportive of the idea.Meanwhile just under one in tenof Scots would ldquostrongly oppose the second lockdown, with another % ldquosomewhat opposing the idea.The remaining % of the responded as ldquodonrsquot know.The YouGov poll surveyed  adults.It comes as figures in Scotland revealed there had been no deaths of people who tested positive for the virus recorded in the past week ndash meaning the toll remains at  ndash and only one in the past  days.The First Minister described this as the ldquoincredible progress made since the country went into lockdown.In the last few weeks Scots have been able to enjoy more freedoms, including the reopening of pubs, restaurants and the tourism sector.Another YouGov poll of the same number of adults revealed that % of people in Scotland would not have a coronavirus vaccine when it became available.The vast majority ndash around %, said they would take the vaccine, with a further % responding as ldquodonrsquot know.

title: former-coastguard-station-turned-beachfront-home
story: East Lothian Councilrsquos planning officials had previously rejected the application to convert the former station, which looks onto East Beach, Dunbar, into a small house after ruling it did not provide enough lsquooutlookrsquo and lsquoamenityrsquo for future occupants.However, a meeting via Skype of the councilrsquos Local Review Body overturned the refusal on appeal after councillors ruled the proposal was better than leaving the building to fall into disrepair.And they questioned whether the design of the new property, which featured extensive glass frontage to let in light, would, in fact, make the amenity more acceptable.Planning officers had estimated the new one-bedroom property would offer just nine square metres of living space in the proposed kitchen living area.The review body was told that there was no set standard for amenity and outlook when it came to conversions like the one put forward for the building, on the townrsquos Lamer Street.Instead, Leigh Taylor, council planning advisor, said it was down to the inidual officer involved.He said: ldquoThere is no exact standard, it is a judgement that has to be made by each case officer.ldquoIn this case, despite the entire east facebeing entirely glazed, it was judged there would not be sufficient outlook and amenity for the occupant.Sutherland and Co Architects Ltd, the agents, had argued that concern about a lack of amenity and outlook for occupants should be dismissed because the property wouldlook out onto the beach, a point they said was made to planners at the time of the original application.In a statement to the review body, they said: ldquoWe made the point that the proposal includes a balcony and ground to the rear for amenity. The site is also opposite the beach.Councillor Sue Kempson, review body member and ward councillor, said she believedit was important to see the building used for a new purpose and did not feel the lack of amenity was a problem, adding: ldquoNot everyone wants a garden.Fellow member Councillor Neil Gilbert agreed, adding: ldquoA building like this, the longer it is left the more it deteriorates. It has to find a new purpose.Councillor Norman Hampshire, review body chairman and ward member, also upheld the appeal.He said: ldquoIt has to have another use either as commercial or residential and I think residential is a good fit for this building. It will give it a long-term future because someone will look after it and keep it to a high standard.The review body agreed unanimously to support the appeal and allow planning permission with conditions for the conversion.

title: hot-tub-suites-looking-sea-among-new-plans-hotel
story: The ambitious proposals would see a three-storey building built between the Bayswell Park Hotel and the clfs to the north.Nine new suites could be created as part of the plans, which would also see a new restaurant built.According to a supporting statement included within the planning application: ldquoThe existing business model is barely sustainable, and the overarching objective of the development is to invest c.pound, in infrastructure improvements to secure the future of the hotel.ldquoThe development proposals will address weaknesses, strengthen the enterprise, promote higher occupancy levels, deliver a much-improved standard of service that will attract customers and, most importantly, facilitate the delivery of a top-quality hotel.The proposals would see changes made to the existing hotel building, as well as the construction of a new annexe.Inside the hotel, which dates back more than  years, four single rooms would be altered to create two double twin rooms.On the western side of the hotel, which is on the townrsquos Bayswell Park, a new dining area would be created.The new -cover restaurant and improved lounge bar would see the removal of the conservatory and the construction of ldquogreatly improved facilities.According to the supporting statement: ldquoThe present areas are too small, and the new restaurant and lounge bar will provide a spacious attractive welcoming ambiance. The comfortable, high-quality dining and relaxation space will be available for both resident guests and for non-resident clients.The new annexe would offer visitors impressive views over the clfs and out to the North Sea.Drawings show the three-storey building ndash with three suites on each floor ndash built into the sloping land, with outdoor hot tubs.The statement reads: ldquoThe existing hot tub suites are spectacularly unique incredibly popular and are delivering high premium occupancy rates and attracting guests to Dunbar from all over Scotland and from the north of England.ldquoThe present number and type of letting rooms is not sufficient to sustain a business model which includes a very high level of service provision ndash particularly when some potential revenue income sources are not deliverableor have greatly declinedndash over recent years.ldquoConsolidation of four single rooms into two double twin rooms will result in the number of bedrooms within the hotel being reduced by two, with the combined proposals showing a net increase of seven rooms.Other works proposed for the hotel include the installation of a lt and ambulant toilet facilities, as well as improving the parking outside the hotel.The proposed developments, which are being weighed up by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department, are the latest changes at the hotel, which currently has  bedrooms and five suites.In , a dining room and conservatory extension was built, and in  a decked area and four private hot tubs were added.Community councillors in the town had mixed views on the proposals, which were discussed on Monday evening.Jacquie Bell, secretary of the group, said there were neighbours who were ldquoreally, really concerned about the proposals.She noted that social media had also given a mixed picture, with some questioning the design of the annexe building and the safety of building on that area of land.However, community councillor Craig Rapson said: ldquoThere is a need for hotel accommodation in Dunbar.ldquoComments about safety issues ndash they are not going to build somethingit is not safe.George Robertson, also a community councillor, agreed that there was a need for improved accommodation in the town and felt the scheme could not be ldquocondemned out right.Ahead of the meeting, Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the group, said that there were mixed views within the community council.She said: ldquoI think we as a community council are going to be guided somewhat by the response of the neighbours.ldquoThe feedback from the community council has been mixed.ldquoThere is a genuine support for anything that would bring a high-quality addition to the accommodation offered in Dunbar.

title: pans-snake-slithers-across-road-new-home
story: The Pans Snake has stretched from the eastern edge of Prestonpans towards neighbouring Cockenzie and Port Seton since it was born at the beginning of April.However, with plans for a temporary cycle path to be created beside busy Edinburgh Road, the snake had to find a new home... on the other side of the road.Emma Orphant was among those spending  minutes on Sunday evening moving the snake from the north side of the road.She said: ldquoWe lost count of the number of stones at ,!ldquoWe moved them across the road because the council are putting in a temporary cycle path.ldquoOn Sunday, volunteers and children moved them across the road.ldquoIt has just been a nice thing for people when they are out for a walk to look for.ldquoIt is for the kids.Youngsters and adults started working on the Pans Snake at the beginning of April, with lockdown restrictions in effect.Similar schemes have taken place where across the country, including the Windygoul Worm in Tranent.The snake started at the bus stop beside the Greenhills at Prestonpans, with Emma, who is depute manager at Seahorse Nursery in Cockenzie, keen to see it stretch the near half-mile to the neighbouring village.Emma, who lives in Prestonpans, was pleased to say that the snake had been a success and admitted she had a few favourite stones.She picked out those from youngsters saying they were missing school or with messages including their name and teacherrsquos name from school as her favourites.Beyond the coronavirus, Emma ndash and a number of people on social media ndash was keen to see the snake find a permanent home, with the possibility of the stones being cemented into the wall beside the footpath.

title: midge-repellents-top-tips-keep-scotlands-biting-beasties-bay
story: The dreaded midge isnt to be trled with. Weve all been there, sitting outside on a warm summers evening and enjoying a sunset, when there comes a tell-tale nip upon exposed flesh. The arm, the leg, the neck, the face, the scalp ndash the midge isnt fussy ndash and before you know it, youre under siege.With more of us set to enjoy staycations this year, we need to learn to coexist with these tiny flying brutes, which is why Im offering up my services as a human guinea pig. Im a good test subject given Ive never met a midge that doesnt like me.I still bear the scars ndash mental and physical ndash of a long weekend in Glen Coe a few years ago. It was July. There was cloud cover, no wind and a sticky humidity. I was almost eaten alive.Scotlands walks are never complete without the dreaded midgeBelieve me, I have tried everything to keep the midges at bay. Among the long list of suggestions that Ive given a whirl are eating Marmite sandwiches, spraying a fine mist of Listerine and taking garlic tablets .Smoke can act as a deterrent, which has seen me huddling next to barbecues and bonfires like they are two-bar electric fires on cold winter mornings.Ive donned midge nets that give me the forlorn air of a beekeeper who has lost her hive, or a grieving Victorian widow. Im considering putting up bat boxes after reading that a lone bat can eat , midges in one night.Citronella and Saltidinare among the ingredients that midges are said to find repugnant and give a wide berth. Essential oils such as eucalyptus, lavender and lemongrass have been credited with similar properties .The midge has a mighty reputation for such a miniscule insect. Weighing just one th of a gram, it has a teeny wingspan of -mm. Midges breed in vast numbers across  per cent of Scotlands land mass.Midges are said to enjoy the smell of our natural body odour and sweat which is where using certain scents can come in handy.Avon Skin So Soft , pound.This moisturiser wasnt designed with midges in mind but has famously been adopted for that purpose. When I interviewed the ultramarathon runner Dean Karnazes in , he mentioned that a friend had advised stocking up on Avon Skin So Soft would be prudent before a visit to Scotland.The Royal Marines are said to swear by its midge-repelling powers when training or based in and around the west coast.The secret to Skin So Soft creating a no-fly zone for midges has been widely attributed to the citronella that it contains.Skin So Soft has been my go-to over the years, clocking up a decent midge-busting hit rate.Application consistency: A dry oil spray.Smell: Baby talcum powder.Verdict: Still a classic. It has won an army of global fans for good reason.Visit avon.ukSmidge , pound.Wandering around shops and supermarkets across the Highlands during the summer months, you will see tourists clutching this elixir.Smidge has been about for a decade now. Its development was led by Dundee-based Dr Alison Blackwell, an authority on midge behaviour and leader of the team behind the Scottish Midge Forecast.The active ingredient is Saltidin which, according to the blurb, "has been molecularly designed to effectively block the antennal receptors of biting insects ndash basically, it throws them off your scent." Smidge is also billed as working on mosquitoes, black flies, sand flies, fleas and ticks.Application consistency: A lightweight, aluminium cannister with pump spray that dispels a fast-absorbing, water-based lotion.Smell: Chic unisex scent. Think CK One.Verdict: Did a stellar job as I sat in my tree-covered garden on a still, humid evening.Visit smidgeupMary Jean Highland Midge Lotion , poundThe idea of making a midge lotion is one that Elizabeth and Mary Quinn struck upon by chance. The owners of family-run Mary Jean in Fochabers, Moray, were selling their skincare products at a Highland Games in .The midges were biting and in a moment of inspiration, Mary soaked some kitchen roll in lemongrass oil and hung it from their stall. It worked a treat and an idea took seed, leading to the creation of Mary Jean Highland Midge Lotion.Ingredients include lemongrass ndash of course ndash as well as bog myrtle, aloe vera, jojoba, neem and mango. It is a wholesome product: handmade, organic, palm oil-free, vegan-friendly and non-toxic. Available in a ml travel size. Can also be used to deter mosquitoes and horseflies.Application consistency: A luxurious and light-feeling cream from a pump dispenser.Smell: Delicious citrus overtones.Verdict: A brilliant product that kept me midge-free. It also helped soothe redness on existing bites.Visit maryjeanAnderson Aromatics Beastie Be Gone , poundBeastie Be Gone, which launched in May, was coined by Bothwell-based clinical aromatherapist and perfumer Julie Anderson-McKee.As someone who loves the outdoors ndash Anderson-McKee can often be found camping in a tent or a caravan by a loch ndash she knows only too well the blight of midges.The result is a triple action cream that combines insect repellent, SPF  protection and a moisturiser that can be used as an after sun. It comes with excellent credentials, including being vegan, hypo-allergenic and as Anderson-McKee puts it "free from all nasties".Tried and tested by  Scottish wild campers and walkers, among the ingredients are organic shea butter, coconut and almond oils, lavender, lemon eucalyptus, citronella and myrrh.Application consistency: A sumptuous cream in a sleek metal container.Smell: Pleasant hints of lemon and lavender.Verdict: An impressive new kid on the block that does what it says on the tin.Visit andersonaromatics

title: scotlands-schools-four-key-updates-parents-ahead-reopening
story: Primary and secondary schools across the country closed their doors back in March to all but a few children.But with coronavirus in Scotland being suppressed to very low levels, things are looking optimistic regarding ato the classroom.Yesterday, education secretary John Swinney provided an update on schools.Teachers:The Scottish Government yesterday announced poundmillion of funding to employ hundreds of teachers and support staff to help schools re-open.An extra poundmillion was also pledged to cover other health protection costs.The funding will equate to around  teachers and  support staff.But as Labourrsquos education spokesperson, Iain Gray, pointed out, that accounts for only half a new member of staff per school across Scotland.August   Councils and schools have been working to the August date for some time.But the Scottish Government will not formally announce the August date until July .The Scottish Government has repeatedly stressed that reducing the infection rate is crucial to the reopening of schools, with the First Minister earlier in the week suggesting no more lockdown changes will be made until pupils are back in the classroom.Mr Swinney stressed that in Scotland, the infection rate is ldquoreducing by  per cent each week, but a sudden surge in cases over the next few weeks could sht the Scottish Governmentrsquos confidence that it is safe to re-open schools.Some pupils may have to socially distanceSocial distancingMr Swinney gave parents some much-needed details about the social distancing guidance that schools will be asked to follow ndash but some questions still remain over how this will work in practice.While primary pupils will not have to socially distance when theyon August , all being well, secondary schools will be told to enforce physical distancing rules ldquowhere possible.Mr Swinney said this was due to the scientic advice on social distancing being ldquoless clear for older pupils.Meanwhile secondary schools will be asked to adjust the layout of classrooms and manage flows of people in and out of buildings ndash but with a catch.This social distancing rule in secondary schools will be ldquosubject always to this not reducing capacity within the school.Youth clubsAs well as earmarking pound million for school staff and pound million to help councils meet extra costs in re-opening classrooms, pound million of previously announced money will be used to support youth work in connection with schools being re-opened.Mr Swinney said this funding has been announced as the sector has ldquocontinued to support and engage children and young people through the pandemic, highlighting the use of digital technology to help mitigate the impact of the lockdown on young peoplersquos mental health.

title: face-masks-scotland-two-key-mistakes-everyone-making
story: So far, just one person has been handed a pound fine for not complying with the rules ndash as the country tries to further control the suppression of the coronavirus.The Scottish Government say that in enclosed spaces, where physical distancing is more dficult with people who are not members of your household, you should wear a face covering.By law, you must wear a covering in shops and on public transport ndash with similar rules coming into force in England today.But there are some parts of the guidance that many people seem to be forgetting.They are:Who Is exempt from wearing a covering Some people are not required to wear a face covering.These include:You are required by law to wear a face covering in Scotlands shops and on public transport .Find out how you can #StaySafe and protect others ##You may also have a reasonable excuse not to wear a face covering , for example:Inidual discretion should be applied in considering the use of face coverings for other children including, for example, children with breathing dficulties and disabled children who would struggle to wear a face covering.

title: 13-unusual-quirky-places-holiday-scotland
story: With the nationrsquos tourism sector now reopened, wersquove put together a list of some of our favourite awe-inspiring holiday accommodation.Places that bring together architectural wizardry and painstaking refurbishment to breathe new le ndash and use ndash into everything from a lighthouse to a modern-day broch and erstwhile modes of transportation, including buses, train carriages and even a helicopter.Roulotte Retreat, near Melrose, Scottish BordersThere is something wonderfully romantic about this circle of seven colourful roulotteslocated in a pretty wildflower meadow below the Eildon Hills.Each roulotte faces onto a lochan at the centre of the site. Facilities include sunset decks, wood-burning stoves, eco saunas and hot tubs. Itrsquos a perfect getaway for nature lovers with owls, deer, foxes, and badgers among the regular visitors.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit roulotteretreatHelicopter Glamping, Mains Farm Wigwams, Thornhill, StirlingStay in a Sea King helicopter complete with mini kitchen, bathroom and a cockpit seating area offering stunning views over the Forth Valley. The helicopter ndash part of Mains Farm Wigwams ndash sleeps two adults or a family of five . Therersquos a double bed, a single bed in the tail and seating which converts into a second double bed. The owners are currently renovating a  Scottish Aviation Twin Pioneer plane set to open for overnight stays next year.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit mainsfarmwigwamsSleeperzzz, Rogart, SutherlandChoose between a vintage railway carriage, a freight wagon or the Waiting Room BB.Located beside a ing train station at Rogart , Sleeperzzz offers budget accommodation for backpackers, families, walkers, cyclists or those who simply fancy spending the night somewhere a bit dferent ndash such as a -ton goods van from the s.A great base for exploring Dunrobin Castle and the North Coast .Prices from poundpp per night. Call   or visit sleeperzzzCraighead Howfs, Dunblane, PerthshireBe transported to The Shire ndash which could be Perthshire or JRR Tolkienrsquos fictional Middle-earth in The Lord of the Rings, depending on how you look at it ndash with these magical Hobbit Howfs.The Burrow and Bagend are built into the hillside with grassy roofs and round doors for an unforgettable glamping experience. Craighead Howfs also offers the chance to stay in a treehouse with panoramic views over the Ochils and a secluded summer house.Prices start from pound per night. Call   or visit craigheadhowfThe Bus Stop, Gford, East LothianIf you have ever wanted to enjoy a Summer Holiday in the vein of the  film, look no further. This fleet of buses in a field belonging to an arable farm in East Lothian have been transformed into holiday accommodation with armchairs, sofas, lanterns, hot flasks, log stoves and beds.Each bus has a private wood-fired hot tub and barbecue fire pit. Choose from rustic or luxury ndash the latter have en suite bathrooms and swish mod cons. Oh, and therersquos gorgeous views of the Lammermuir Hills.Prices from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit thebusstop.scotBrockloch Eco Retreat, Kirkpatrick Durham, Castle DouglasFeatured on George Clarkersquos Amazing Spaces, Brockloch Eco Retreat is small but perfectly formed. Located on a working farm, therersquos two units: a contemporary, off-grid, micro-timber bothy facing into an open field and an incredible treehouse hideaway within a bluebell wood where the closest neighbours are red squirrels.The treehouse has a built-in double bed with a skylight to gaze at the treetops and stars as you drt off to sleep. This part of the world is a great place to see red kites.Prices from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit brocklochBlack Isle Yurts, Eathie Hill, RosemarkieSet in private woodland, all of the yurts within this eco-sensitive, wild-glamping site are based on designs used by nomadic people in Central Asia for thousands of years.In keeping with the Scottish climate, the traditional felt outer shell has been replaced with a waterproof canvas and therersquos a wood-burning stove to stay cosy on cooler nights. The site is a short drive from Chanonry Point which is fantastic for dolphin spotting.Prices from pound for a two-night stay. Call   or visit blackisleyurtsRua Reidh Lighthouse, near Gairloch, Wester RossBuilt in  by David Alan Stevenson, a cousin of the writer Robert Louis Stevenson and one of the famous ldquoLighthouse Stevensons, this beautul, remote location offers BB and self-catering, the latter in the charmingly named First Officerrsquos Quarters.Endless views, a glorious stretch of coastline, abundant bird and sea le, tranquillity, solitude and the thrill of potentially catching a glimpse of the Aurora Borealis on dark, starry nights awaits.Prices start from pound per night. title: big-changes-furlough-scheme-august-1----need-know
story: Employers across the UK have until Friday to submit claims for furloughed staff for periods ending on or before June .The UK Government introduced new rules at the start of the month, allowing furloughed employees back to work for any amount of time or sht pattern.Employers would pay the wages for those days, with the UK Government still pay the % grant ndash up to a cap of pound per month ndash on the days not worked.But from Saturday, August , more major changes are to come into effect.What are the changes From Saturday, the level of grant will be reduced each month until the scheme ends on October .Chancellor Rishi SunakWhat does this mean for employers From this date, employers will be required to start contributing more eachmonth.They will also have to start paying National Insurance Contributions and pension contributions for the hours the employee is on furlough.From September , employers will be made to contribute % towards the wage payments ndash which will be added on to % provided by the UK Government.And From October , employers will have to contribute %, added on to % by the UK Government.Full details can be found here.What does this mean for furloughed staff The good news for you is that your wages will remain the same.You will continue to receive % of your salary ndash but the dference is just the adjustment of what your employer pays, and what the state title: coronavirus-pet-cat-becomes-first-animal-uk-confirmed-case
story: Heres the latest on what we know so far.When was the test carried out The infection was confirmed following tests at the Animal and Plant Health Agencylaboratory in Weybridge, Surrey, on Wednesday, July .What have Public Health England said Yvonne Doyle, medical director at Public Health England , said: ldquoThis is the first case of a domestic cat testing positive for Covid- in the UK but should not be a cause for alarm.ldquoThe investigation into this case suggests that the infection was spread from humans to animal, and not the other way round.ldquoAt this time, there is no evidence that pets can transmit the disease to humans.ldquoIn line with the general advice on fighting coronavirus, you should wash your hands regularly, including before and after contact with animals.A private vet initially diagnosed the pet with feline herpes virus, a common cat respiratory infection, but the sample was also tested for Covid- part of a research programme.The case has been reported to the World Organisation for Animal Health in line with international agreements.Have other cases in pets been reported There have been a small number of confirmed cases in pets in other countries in Europe, North America and Asia.What has the UKs chief veterinary officer said The UKrsquos chief veterinary officer, Christine Middlemiss, said: ldquoTests conducted by the Animal and Plant Health Agency have confirmed that the virus responsible for Covid- has been detected in a pet cat in England.ldquoThis is a very rare event, with infected animals detected to date only showing mild clinical signs and recovering within a few days.ldquoThere is no evidence to suggest that pets directly transmit the virus to humans.ldquoWe will continue to monitor this situation closely and will update our guidance to pet owners should the situation change.

title: covid-19-testing-centre-returns-former-power-station-site
story: It re-started todayand runs until Wednesday at the site on Edinburgh Road, am-pm.Tests can be booked through the UK Governmentrsquos online system, www.gov.uk get-coronavirus-test, for those who are key workers or those who live with one.Alternatively they can be booked through the NHS website at www.nhs.uk conditions coronavirus-covid-A limited number of home testing kits are available for those who cannot make it to the testing site, but priority will continue to be given to key workers and can be secured by booking through their employer.As of May , testing is for people who have symptoms and are over the age of five as well as household members who are experiencing symptoms.Symptoms include a new continuous cough, a fever and a loss or change in smell or taste.Anyone who develops symptoms is asked to self-isolate immediately as well as all members of their household until they receive a negative test result.More information on testing is available at www.gov.scot publications coronavirus-covid--getting-testedThis is not the first time Covid- testing has taken place at the former power station site.A mobile testing unit first visited the site between May  and  and later visited again from May -June .It was operated by the st Infantry Brigade which oversees the army reserve units in Scotland.
